title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam in the 7th century CE?

options.label: A
options.text: Abū Bakr

options.label: B
options.text: Muhammad

options.label: C
options.text: Ali

options.label: D
options.text: The Umayyad Dynasty

multiple-choice.question: What type of leader was Muhammad, and what was the nature of the alliance he formed?

options.label: A
options.text: A purely religious leader, with a focus on spiritual guidance

options.label: B
options.text: A one-of-a-kind leader, with an alliance that was both political and religious

options.label: C
options.text: A military leader, with a focus on conquest

options.label: D
options.text: A tribal leader, with a focus on uniting the Quraysh tribe

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the deliberation among Muhammad's close companions after his death?

options.label: A
options.text: Abū Bakr was chosen as the new caliph

options.label: B
options.text: Ali was chosen as the new caliph

options.label: C
options.text: The Umayyad Dynasty came to power

options.label: D
options.text: The Abbasid family was chosen to lead

multiple-choice.question: How did the Umayyads stabilize the empire after its vast expansion?

options.label: A
options.text: By imposing Islam on all local populations

options.label: B
options.text: By replacing the ruling elite with Muslim officials and allowing local customs to continue

options.label: C
options.text: By making Arabic the only language spoken in the empire

options.label: D
options.text: By relocating the capital to Baghdad

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the dissatisfaction with Umayyad rule among many in the empire?

options.label: A
options.text: The Umayyads were not direct descendants of Muhammad

options.label: B
options.text: The Umayyads were too tolerant of local customs

options.label: C
options.text: The Umayyads were too focused on military conquest

options.label: D
options.text: The Umayyads were not wealthy enough

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Abbasid family's promotion of themselves as more direct descendants of Muhammad?

options.label: A
options.text: They were rejected by the people

options.label: B
options.text: They were accepted as the new rulers, but only in Baghdad

options.label: C
options.text: They overthrew the Umayyad caliphate and became the second great dynasty of the Islamic Empire

options.label: D
options.text: They were forced to relocate the capital

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the extensive trade networks under Abbasid rule?

options.label: A
options.text: The elite suffered from poverty

options.label: B
options.text: The caliph was weakened

options.label: C
options.text: The elite enjoyed a lifestyle of luxury, and artistic and scientific advancements were made

options.label: D
options.text: The empire was isolated from the rest of the world

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem with the line of succession in the Abbasid caliphate?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the caliph's son could succeed him

options.label: B
options.text: There was a clear line of succession, but it was often ignored

options.label: C
options.text: Any male relative of the former caliph was eligible, leading to power struggles

options.label: D
options.text: The caliph was always chosen by the people

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Mongols' approach to Baghdad in 1258 CE?

options.label: A
options.text: The city was defended successfully

options.label: B
options.text: The Mongols were defeated

options.label: C
options.text: The city was thoroughly destroyed, and the caliph was killed

options.label: D
options.text: The Mongols were welcomed as liberators

multiple-choice.question: What was the lasting impact of the Islamic Empire on the world?

options.label: A
options.text: The spread of Christianity

options.label: B
options.text: The spread of Islam, written and spoken Arabic, and the ideas of its greatest intellectuals

options.label: C
options.text: The rise of the Mongols

options.label: D
options.text: The decline of trade networks

title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial suspicion of the museum curator when inspecting the portrait attributed to Bronzino?

options.label: A
options.text: That it was painted in the 19th century

options.label: B
options.text: That it was a modern fake

options.label: C
options.text: That it was from the Italian Medici dynasty

options.label: D
options.text: That it was painted by one of Bronzino's students

multiple-choice.question: What technology was used to discover the countenance of a completely different woman under the outer surface of paint in the portrait?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Infrared technology

options.label: C
options.text: Ultraviolet technology

options.label: D
options.text: Magnetic resonance technology

options.label: A
options.text: They try to improve the art

options.label: B
options.text: They make their markings visually and chemically distinct from the original

options.label: C
options.text: They remove the original varnish coat

options.label: D
options.text: They use heavy-handed techniques

multiple-choice.question: Why do older paintings often have a yellowy look?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the natural aging process

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the type of paint used

options.label: C
options.text: Because the natural varnishes applied eventually darkened

options.label: D
options.text: Because of exposure to sunlight

multiple-choice.question: What was the likely reason for the Victorian makeover of the portrait of Isabella?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the painting more attractive

options.label: B
options.text: To boost sales because the original subject wasn't considered attractive

options.label: C
options.text: To change the style of the painting

options.label: D
options.text: To make the painting more valuable

multiple-choice.question: What was altered in Bronzino's painting "An Allegory with Venus and Cupid" to make it less risqué for Victorian England?

options.label: A
options.text: Venus's face was covered

options.label: B
options.text: Venus's tongue and nipple were obscured

options.label: C
options.text: Cupid's face was covered

options.label: D
options.text: The background was changed

multiple-choice.question: What was used to analyze and remove the overpainting in "An Allegory with Venus and Cupid"?

options.label: A
options.text: X-ray technology

options.label: B
options.text: Select solvents

options.label: C
options.text: Infrared technology

options.label: D
options.text: Ultraviolet technology

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Rembrandt's painting "The Night Watch" in 1715?

options.label: A
options.text: It was stolen

options.label: B
options.text: It was damaged in a fire

options.label: C
options.text: Strips were removed from all sides of the canvas to fit it inside Amsterdam's Town Hall

options.label: D
options.text: It was sold to a private collector

multiple-choice.question: How were the missing pieces of "The Night Watch" replaced in the 2019 conservation project?

options.label: A
options.text: By using another artist's rendering of the original

options.label: B
options.text: By training an artificial intelligence to digitally paint in Rembrandt's style

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: By manually repainting the missing sections

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of art conservators when working on priceless artifacts?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the artifacts more valuable

options.label: B
options.text: To make the artifacts more attractive

options.label: C
options.text: To immortalize the artifacts

options.label: D
options.text: To change the style of the artifacts

options.label: B
options.text: Conductive materials have weakly bound electrons

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: They were more sensitive

options.label: D
options.text: They were less efficient

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To connect the conductive lines to the phone's battery

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Because the body is made up of mostly air

options.label: B
options.text: Because the body is made up of mostly water, which is a conductor when impure

options.label: C
options.text: Because the body is made up of mostly metal

options.label: D
options.text: Because the body is made up of mostly plastic

options.text: The phone becomes less sensitive

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are made up of mostly water

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are made up of mostly metal

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The phone acts like multiple parts of the screen are being touched at once

options.label: D

title: The true cost of gold - Lyla Latif

options.text: 100 tons

options.text: 200 tons

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: To pay taxes on time

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: Who invented the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the 1930s?

options.label: A
options.text: King Jigme Singye Wangchuk

options.label: B
options.text: Simon Kuznets

options.label: C
options.text: Milton Friedman

options.label: D
options.text: John Maynard Keynes

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of using GDP as a measure of well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It only measures economic growth in developed countries.

options.label: B
options.text: It doesn't take into account what a country produces or who has access to it.

options.label: C
options.text: It only measures the total monetary value of goods and services.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used by governments and not by businesses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between GDP and GDP per capita?

options.label: A
options.text: GDP measures the total monetary value of goods and services, while GDP per capita measures the total number of people living in a country.

options.label: B
options.text: GDP per capita is the total GDP divided by the number of people living in that country.

options.label: C
options.text: GDP measures economic growth, while GDP per capita measures population growth.

options.label: D
options.text: GDP is used by governments, while GDP per capita is used by businesses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the United Nations' Human Development Index (HDI)?

options.label: A
options.text: A metric that measures a country's economic growth.

options.label: B
options.text: A metric that measures a country's environmental sustainability.

options.label: C
options.text: A metric that takes into account health, education, and income per capita to estimate overall well-being.

options.label: D
options.text: A metric that measures a country's GDP per capita.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using a dashboard approach to measure a country's well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a single number that is easy to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: It takes into account all the factors that a single number obscures.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only used by experts and not by governments.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a more widely used metric than GDP.

multiple-choice.question: Which country is currently closest to meeting the basic needs of its people while also using resources fully sustainably?

options.label: A
options.text: Costa Rica

options.label: B
options.text: Colombia

options.label: C
options.text: Jordan

options.label: D
options.text: United States

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the Sustainable Development Index and the Human Development Index?

options.label: A
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index takes into account environmental burdens, while the Human Development Index does not.

options.label: B
options.text: The Human Development Index takes into account environmental burdens, while the Sustainable Development Index does not.

options.label: C
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index is used by governments, while the Human Development Index is used by businesses.

options.label: D
options.text: The Human Development Index is a more widely used metric than the Sustainable Development Index.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the relationship between GDP growth and wage growth in many Western economies in the 1980s?

options.label: A
options.text: Wages continued to grow proportionally with GDP growth.

options.label: B
options.text: Wages stopped keeping pace with GDP growth or even declined.

options.label: C
options.text: GDP growth slowed down, while wage growth increased.

options.label: D
options.text: The relationship between GDP growth and wage growth remained the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is Gross National Happiness, and who came up with the idea?

options.label: A
options.text: Gross National Happiness is a metric that measures a country's economic growth, and it was invented by Simon Kuznets.

options.label: B
options.text: Gross National Happiness is a metric that factors in matters like health, education, and living standards, and it was invented by King Jigme Singye Wangchuk.

options.label: C
options.text: Gross National Happiness is a metric that measures a country's environmental sustainability, and it was invented by Milton Friedman.

options.label: D
options.text: Gross National Happiness is a metric that measures a country's GDP per capita, and it was invented by John Maynard Keynes.

multiple-choice.question: Why do experts increasingly favor a dashboard approach to measuring a country's well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it provides a single number that is easy to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it takes into account all the factors that a single number obscures.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a more widely used metric than GDP.

options.label: D
options.text: Because people have different priorities, and a dashboard approach allows for a more nuanced understanding of well-being.

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

multiple-choice.question: What is the British Museum, and what is its significance in the world of history and culture?

options.label: A
options.text: The British Museum is a small, local museum in London that houses a few thousand artifacts.

options.label: B
options.text: The British Museum is the world's largest world history museum, with over 8 million cultural and historical artifacts from around the world.

options.label: C
options.text: The British Museum is a museum of natural history, focusing on the evolution of species and the natural world.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Museum is a museum of modern art, showcasing contemporary artists from around the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with some of the artifacts in the British Museum, and why is it a subject of debate?

options.label: A
options.text: The problem is that some artifacts are too old and fragile to be displayed, and the debate is about how to preserve them.

options.label: B
options.text: The problem is that some artifacts have disputed ownership, and the debate is about whether they should be returned to their countries of origin.

options.label: C
options.text: The problem is that some artifacts are too valuable to be displayed, and the debate is about how to protect them from theft.

options.label: D
options.text: The problem is that some artifacts are not relevant to British history, and the debate is about whether they should be removed from the museum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the history behind the Benin Bronzes, and how did they end up in the British Museum?

options.label: A
options.text: The Benin Bronzes were created in ancient Greece and were brought to the British Museum by British archaeologists.

options.label: B
options.text: The Benin Bronzes were created in the Kingdom of Benin in present-day Nigeria and were taken by British troops during the Benin Punitive Expedition in 1897.

options.label: C
options.text: The Benin Bronzes were created in ancient Egypt and were brought to the British Museum by British collectors.

options.label: D
options.text: The Benin Bronzes were created in modern times and were donated to the British Museum by a Nigerian artist.

multiple-choice.question: What is the British Museum's stance on returning artifacts to their countries of origin?

options.label: A
options.text: The British Museum is committed to returning all artifacts to their countries of origin.

options.label: B
options.text: The British Museum is restricted by a government act that prevents it from returning objects, but it is committed to lending them to other museums.

options.label: C
options.text: The British Museum believes that all artifacts should be kept in British museums, regardless of their origin.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Museum has no stance on the issue and leaves it up to individual curators to decide.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Benin Bronzes to the people of Nigeria, and why are they important to their cultural heritage?

options.label: A
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the people of Nigeria because they are valuable and could be sold for a high price.

options.label: B
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the people of Nigeria because they are a part of their cultural heritage and represent their history and identity.

options.label: C
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the people of Nigeria because they are beautiful works of art and could be displayed in a Nigerian museum.

options.label: D
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the people of Nigeria because they are a reminder of their colonial past and the exploitation they suffered.

multiple-choice.question: How do you think the British Museum should handle the issue of disputed ownership of artifacts? (Application question)

options.label: A
options.text: The British Museum should return all artifacts to their countries of origin, regardless of how they were acquired.

options.label: B
options.text: The British Museum should keep all artifacts in its collection, regardless of their origin, and make them available to the public.

options.label: C
options.text: The British Museum should work with the countries of origin to find a solution that benefits both parties, such as lending or repatriating artifacts.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Museum should ignore the issue and focus on acquiring new artifacts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the broader legacy of colonialism and its impact on cultural heritage? (Analytical question)

options.label: A
options.text: The legacy of colonialism is one of cultural exchange and enrichment, where different cultures were able to share and learn from each other.

options.label: B
options.text: The legacy of colonialism is one of exploitation and cultural destruction, where colonizers took cultural artifacts and destroyed the cultural heritage of the colonized.

options.label: C
options.text: The legacy of colonialism is one of cultural preservation, where colonizers helped to preserve the cultural heritage of the colonized.

options.label: D
options.text: The legacy of colonialism is one of cultural assimilation, where the colonized were forced to adopt the culture of the colonizers.

multiple-choice.question: How do you think the issue of disputed ownership of artifacts can be resolved? (Application question)

options.label: A
options.text: The issue can be resolved through international agreements and laws that regulate the trade and ownership of cultural artifacts.

options.label: B
options.text: The issue can be resolved through dialogue and negotiation between museums and the countries of origin.

options.label: C
options.text: The issue can be resolved through the return of all artifacts to their countries of origin.

options.label: D
options.text: The issue can be resolved through the creation of a new international museum that houses all disputed artifacts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Benin Bronzes to the British Museum, and why are they important to its collection? (Conceptual question)

options.label: A
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the British Museum because they are a part of its collection and represent the cultural heritage of the British Empire.

options.label: B
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the British Museum because they are a part of its collection and represent the cultural heritage of Nigeria.

options.label: C
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the British Museum because they are valuable and rare artifacts that are important to the study of African art.

options.label: D
options.text: The Benin Bronzes are significant to the British Museum because they are a reminder of the colonial past and the exploitation of Nigeria.

multiple-choice.question: How do you think the British Museum can balance its role as a custodian of cultural heritage with the demands of countries of origin for the return of their artifacts? (Application question)

options.label: A
options.text: The British Museum can balance its role by returning all artifacts to their countries of origin.

options.label: B
options.text: The British Museum can balance its role by keeping all artifacts in its collection and making them available to the public.

options.label: C
options.text: The British Museum can balance its role by working with countries of origin to find a solution that benefits both parties, such as lending or repatriating artifacts.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Museum can balance its role by ignoring the demands of countries of origin and focusing on acquiring new artifacts.

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

options.label: C
